entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM Integration with Microsoft Teams for Chat Notifications
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM can forward events to external chat tools to create messages in chat channels. This blog elaborates integration between Cloud ALM and MS teams to provide real-time chat notifications directly in your Teams workspace!

Here’s how easy it is to set up:

Step 1: In Microsoft Teams, create a Team.  Click Teams > New team.

  • Team Name: CALM Notifications
  • Description: Optional
  • Team Type: Private
  • First Channel Name: Default General
  • Click on Create

Add any users you wish to participate in the Teams Channel (as the creator, you are added already) instead click Skip:

Now, The Team and General Channel were created.

In General, click …(Three dots) and select Manage Channel --> Settings --> Connectors --> Edit --> Search for Incoming Webhook --> Add. Once it is added click on Configure.

Enter a Name for webhook and there is an option to upload you're organization image if required and click Save.

The Webhook URL is created.  Click Copy and paste the URL in a notepad for later.  Click Save:

Step 2: Logon to BTP Cockpit and access Global Cloud ALM > Cloud ALM Subaccount

Click Connectivity > Destinations > Create Destination:

In Destination Configuration, Enter a Name, a Description and get URL from Teams webhook creation which is saved in notepad and click Save:

 

 
Destination is created

 

Step 3: In SAP Cloud ALM launchpad, click Administration > External API Management

Click Mappings Management > Copy for an existing mapping : Event situations in MS teams Chat and rename it to one you’ll recognize as yours (this autosaves)

Click Webhooks Management > +

Enter a value in Name, use F4 help to select the Destination ID created in step 2 and in Destination Type, select Microsoft Teams:

Click External Resource Type and select Chat and click Save.

Click Subscription Management > +, fill Name and set Resource type to Event Situation

Set Mapping & Webhook to the value created above and set Type to Built-in and click Save

In SAP Cloud ALM for Operations > Any use case, ensure Scope is set to include system where Send Chat action is to be configured.

 

Click Configuration, set service/system with desired config, for example: Systems > click link for system

 

Click Events tab

 

For the Metric desired, e.g. Data collection failed, click >

 

In the case the chat notification should contain info on the Alert, set Create Alert > ON:

To trigger the Chat, set Send Chat Notification > ON and click + to select the subscription name created above and click Save

 

Allow data collection job to run (default 5 minutes). If the enabled metric breaches the threshold a chat notification will be triggered to your teams channel.

 

 
Conclusion:
Setting up real-time notifications from SAP Cloud ALM directly into Microsoft Teams brings a new level of visibility and responsiveness to your operations. With this integration, your teams can stay up to date with critical events and alerts right where they collaborate every day, enabling instant action and reducing response times. The process is straightforward—by connecting Cloud ALM’s event forwarding capabilities with Teams’ Incoming Webhook, important situations are surfaced immediately to the right people, in the right channel.
 
#SAPCLOUDALM #MSTEAMS

entry.title: Actions in RAP ABAP in Unmanaged BO and List Report with COPY Action
entry.content:
Introduction :

This document explains how to implement a custom instance action (COPY) in a managed RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) application. The scenario is based on a custom Product business object, where a selected product record can be copied to create a new one with adjusted values. The implementation covers the complete RAP flow: creating a custom database table, defining Interface and Composite (Projection) Views, metadata definitions, and behavior definitions. It also demonstrates how to implement the action logic in the behavior implementation class and expose the action to a SAP Fiori Elements application using annotations. Finally, the solution shows how to publish and consume the OData service and generate a List Report application in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).

  1. Create a custom table (preferably, but you may use a standard table if needed) on which you will perform a series of actions or operations.
  2. You need to create an Interface View and the Composite View.
  3. Create the meta data definition for the Composite View.
  4. Create behavior definitions for both the Interface and Composite Views.
  5. You can find these steps in the following blog
    CRUD Operations in RAP ABAP in managed BO - SAP Community
  6. From Here the actual Topic Starts Actions that are to be implemented.

COPY Of a Record

  • Just define the action that is to be handled in your application. Here I have used the Action COPY.

  •  

managed implementation in class zbp_i_vbproduct_vw unique;
strict ( 2 );
//with draft;
define behavior for ZI_VBPRODUCT_VW alias Product
persistent table zvb_product
//draft table zvb_product_d
lock master

//total etag Localdate
authorization master ( instance )
etag master Localdate
{
  create;
  update;
  delete;
//   draft action Edit;
//    draft determine action Prepare;
//   draft action Activate;
// draft action Discard;
// draft action Resume;
//field ( readonly ) productid;
 factory action Copy[1];
  mapping for zvb_product
{
  ProductId = product_id;
  Name       = name;
  Category   = category;
  Price      = price;
  Currency   = currency;
  Discount   = discount;
  Localdate = localdate;
  createdtime = createdtime;
  CreatedBy = createdby;
}
}​
  •  Now you have to implement the method in the class that is defined in the interface Behavior definition.

  •  

CLASS lhc_Product DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.

    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR Product RESULT result.
    METHODS copy FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR ACTION product~copy.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lhc_Product IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD get_instance_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.
METHOD copy.

  DATA:
    products TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE zi_vbproduct_vw,
    lv_prod_id TYPE zi_vbproduct_vw-productid.

  " Ensure no keys with initial %cid
  READ TABLE keys WITH KEY %cid = '' INTO DATA(key_with_initial_cid).
  ASSERT key_with_initial_cid IS INITIAL.

  " Step 1: Read existing product data
  READ ENTITIES OF zi_vbproduct_vw IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY product
    ALL FIELDS WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
    RESULT DATA(product_read_result)
    FAILED failed.

  " Step 2: Determine starting product ID
  SELECT MAX( productid ) FROM zi_vbproduct_vw INTO _prod_id.

  " Step 3: Prepare new product instances
  LOOP AT product_read_result ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<product>).

    DATA(new_product_id) = lv_prod_id + 1.
    lv_prod_id = new_product_id.

    APPEND VALUE #(
      %cid      = keys[ KEY entity %key = <product>-%key ]-%cid
*      %is_draft = keys[ KEY entity %key = <product>-%key ]-%param-%is_draft
      %data     = VALUE #(
        productid = new_product_id
        name      = <product>-name
        category  = <product>-category
        price     = <product>-price * ( 1 - ( <product>-discount / 100 ) )
        currency  = <product>-currency
        discount  = <product>-discount
        localdate = sy-datum
        createdby = sy-uname
      )
    ) TO products.

  ENDLOOP.

  " Step 4: Create new product instances
  MODIFY ENTITIES OF zi_vbproduct_vw IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY product
    CREATE FIELDS ( productid name category price currency discount localdate createdby )
    WITH products
    MAPPED DATA(mapped_create).

  " Step 5: Set mapped result
  mapped-product = mapped_create-product.

ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.​
  • Use action in the Composite View Behaviour definition.
  • ￼

     

projection;
strict ( 2 );
//use draft;
define behavior for ZC_VB_PROJ_PRODUCT alias Product
implementation in class zbp_i_vbproduct_vw unique
{
  use create;
  use update;
  use delete;
//   use action Edit;
// use action Prepare;
// use action Activate;
// use action Discard;
// use action Resume;
use action Copy;
 mapping for zvb_product

{
  ProductId = product_id;
  Name       = name;
  Category   = category;
  Price      = price;
  Currency   = currency;
  Discount   = discount;
  Localdate = localdate;
  createdtime = createdtime;
  CreatedBy = createdby;
}
}​
  •  To display the button in the Fiori application you must have the following code in your metadata extension.
{ type: #FOR_ACTION , label: 'Copy', dataAction: 'Copy'   }​
  • If you want the button in the Line-item page, you must mention the action in the @ui.lineitem annotation or you need in the object page then you have to use in @ui.identification annotation
@Metadata.layer: #CORE
@UI: { 

  headerInfo: { 

    typeName: 'Product', 
    typeNamePlural: 'Product', 
    title: { type: #STANDARD , label: 'Product', value: 'ProductId' } 
    
    }
    }
annotate view ZC_VB_PROJ_PRODUCT
    with 
{
      .facet: [{ id: 'product_id', purpose: #STANDARD, type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE, label: 'product_id', position: 10 }] 

  : { lineItem: [{ position: 10 },{ type: #FOR_ACTION , label: 'Copy', dataAction: 'Copy'   }] ,selectionField: [{ position: 20 }], 

  identification: [{ position: 10, label: 'Product ID' }] } 

    ProductId ; 

    : { lineItem: [{ position: 20 }], identification: [{ position: 20, label: 'Name' }], selectionField: [{ position: 30 }] } 

    Name; 

        : { lineItem: [{ position: 30 }], identification: [{ position: 30, label: 'Category' }],selectionField: [{ position: 40 }]} 

    Category; 

     : { lineItem: [{ position: 40 }], identification: [{ position: 40,label: 'Price' }],selectionField: [{ position: 50 }]} 

    Price; 

     : { lineItem: [{ position: 50}], identification: [{ position: 50, label: 'Currency' }],selectionField: [{ position: 60 }]} 

    Currency; 
    .lineItem: [{  position: 60 }]
    .identification: [{ position: 60, label: 'Discount'  }]
    .selectionField: [{  position: 70 }]
    Discount; 
     .lineItem: [{  position: 70 }]
    .identification: [{ position: 70, label: 'Created Date'  }]
    .selectionField: [{  position: 80 }]
    Localdate;
     .lineItem: [{  position: 80 }]
    .identification: [{ position: 80, label: 'Created Time'  }]
    .selectionField: [{  position: 90 }]
    createdtime;
     .lineItem: [{  position: 90 }]
    .identification: [{ position: 90, label: 'Created By'  }]
    .selectionField: [{  position: 100 }]
    CreatedBy;
    
}

 

6.  Finally Create a Service definition for the Consumption view and Service binding for that service definition. then activate the Service binding and publish the Service Binding for View it. 

Click on Preview.

 

                                                                       Final Output

You can see the button here in the Fiori application

As it is an instance action you can see it enabled when you select the record.

When you click on the COPY Button you can see the Created record in the object page.

Finally, you can see the copied record in the list report

USAGE OF The ODATA Service in SAP Business application Studio

Use the Service Binding Name to create a list report in the BAS

Follow below steps to create a list report

  • Open BAS
  • Click on SAP Fiori generator and click on Next. 
  •  

     

  • Click on List Report Page and Next.                                                                                   

     

  • Select the data Source, System and Service     
  •  

     

  • Select the Main Entity and Type and Click on Next. 
  •   

     

  • Finally give the module name, application name and Name space if needed

  •  

  • After Creating the project right click on the application and preview application

     

  • Final Output is as follows 

  • Summary

    In this implementation, a managed RAP business object is enhanced with a COPY instance action that duplicates an existing product record. The action is defined in the Interface View behavior, implemented in the behavior handler class, and then exposed in the Composite (Projection) View. Metadata extensions are used to display the COPY button in the Fiori UI, either in the line item or object page. Once the service definition and binding are created and published, the OData service is consumed in BAS to generate a List Report application. The final result is a fully functional Fiori application where users can select a product, trigger the COPY action, and immediately see the newly created record in both the object page and the list report.

Thank You,

Bharath Kumar V

entry.title: Re: IDoc port -system port SAPxxx
entry.content:
SAP<system> is a dummy conventional port name to be used:

  • As the receiver port (EDIDC-RCVPOR) if it's an Inbound IDoc generated by ABAP program.
  • As the sender port (EDIDC-SNDPOR) if it's an Outbound IDoc generated by ABAP program.

It cannot be defined in WE21.

entry.title: Re: Display In-Progress Workflows in Compensation Forms during Annual Salary Review
entry.content:
Hi @aaditya0710 

Congrats on your first blog !

Question I would have on the business requirement is : what if the off cycle increase doesn't go through ? Then employee gets ignored both in EC and in Comp review.

Usually for this "topic" we recommend to have a field in CompInfo called "Date of Last of Salary Increase" with on Save business rule (can have specific conditions such as only trigger when specific type of increase is given) that copies the event date into the field once workflow is approved. We reference that date in our compensation eligibility rules and we grey out the employees on the worksheets with the overnight Mass Update Job. It removes the recommendation they already received automatically (and updates the budget).

Best,

Xavier

entry.title: Extending an SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget in SAP Analytics Cloud to Deliver Top-N Hierarchical In
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) does not provide a native, built-in Sankey chart as part of its standard visualization catalog. As a result, Sankey-style visualizations in SAC are typically implemented using custom widgets.

In mid-2024, while working on an enterprise analytics engagement, I encountered a requirement to visualize:

  • Top N parent entities (for example, service providers)
  • And, for each parent, the Top M child entities independently ranked per parent (for example, services offered)

All of this needed to be displayed within a single Sankey visualization, enabling users to immediately understand concentration and distribution patterns without navigating multiple charts.

To address this requirement, I explored SAC’s Custom Widget framework and extended an existing SAP-provided sample Sankey custom widget into a production-ready solution.

I have intentionally included the development and deployment steps in detail so that consultants or developers who are completely new to Sankey custom widgets in SAP Analytics Cloud can deploy and validate the solution end-to-end by following this blog.

SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget as the Starting Point

Since SAP Analytics Cloud does not include a native Sankey chart, I referred to a sample Sankey custom widget implementation shared by SAP through the SAP Community. This SAP-provided sample demonstrates how a Sankey diagram can be rendered using the SAC Custom Widget framework and served as a technical starting point for my work.

The SAP sample was very helpful as a technical reference, as it illustrated:

  • Custom widget structure and lifecycle
  • Binding SAC model data to a widget
  • Rendering a Sankey diagram using JavaScript

During mid-2024, while actively working on this requirement, I engaged in the comments section of that SAP Community blog (SAP Analytics Cloud: Custom Widget & Widget Add-Ons Samples Preview) under my SAP Community user@GovindaRaoBanothu45 , discussing feasibility and implementation boundaries.

While the sample clarified the basic rendering approach, it also highlighted functional gaps when applied to enterprise-scale analytical requirements.

Why the SAP Sample Sankey Widget Was Not Sufficient

The SAP-provided Sankey custom widget was intentionally designed as a generic sample. Its behavior was to render all nodes and all links returned by the bound dataset.

However, the sample widget did not support the enterprise analytical requirement I was addressing, specifically:

  • No Top-N filtering at the parent level
  • No independent ranking of child nodes per parent
  • No data trimming prior to Sankey rendering
  • Limited usability for large, real-world datasets

As a result, while the SAP sample demonstrated how to render a Sankey chart, it did not meet the analytical or usability needs of an enterprise dashboard.

This gap required extending and enhancing the SAP sample Sankey custom widget with additional, original logic to reshape the dataset before rendering.

High-Level Architecture of the Extended Sankey Widget

The Sankey rendering mechanism remains aligned with the SAP sample, while the data-transformation layer represents the core extension.

Development Environment and Prerequisites

Prerequisites

To get started, ensure that you have:

  • Access to SAP Analytics Cloud with Optimized Design Experience enabled
  • Node.js installed on your local machine
  • Visual Studio Code (VS Code) installed
  • Basic understanding of JavaScript and JSON

Development Environment Setup

Install Node.js

  1. Download Node.js from: https://nodejs.org
  2. Verify installation:
node -v
npm -v

Install Visual Studio Code

  1. Download VS Code from: https://code.visualstudio.com
  2. Use VS Code as the primary editor for developing and maintaining the custom widget files.

Set Up the Project Folder

  1. Create a project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode).
  2. Open the folder in Visual Studio Code.
  3. Create the following files:
  • main.js – core widget logic and Sankey rendering
  • index.json – metadata and resource configuration
  • hash256.js – Node.js script for integrity key generation

Sankey Custom Widget – Standard Project Structure

For the standard Sankey implementation, I created a dedicated project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode or any relevant project name). This folder contains all the supporting and required files needed to build and deploy the Sankey custom widget in SAP Analytics Cloud.

The project folder includes:

  • main.js
    The web component JavaScript file that contains the core widget logic and Sankey rendering code (mandatory).
  • index.json
    The metadata file that defines the custom widget, its properties, and resource references (mandatory).
  • sankeyChartStyling.js
    An optional styling component used to expose styling options in the widget’s styling panel (optional).
  • build/ folder
    Contains the helper script hash256.js, which is used to generate SHA-256 integrity keys for the JavaScript files.

Note: Styling files (Styling.js, sankeyChartStyling.js, or xxxxStyling.js) are optional and may not be required for all custom widgets.
However, the web component JavaScript file (main.js or equivalent) and the metadata file (index.json) are mandatory for every SAP Analytics Cloud custom widget. The build folder is included purely for maintainability and ease of understanding.
Technically, the hash256.js file can also be placed directly in the main project folder. Including it in a separate subfolder is optional and does not impact deployment, as long as the final ZIP file complies with SAP Analytics Cloud’s upload requirements.

Creating Integrity Keys and Deploying the Code

SAP Analytics Cloud supports SHA-256 integrity validation to ensure uploaded JavaScript resources are not modified.

Generating Integrity Keys

  1. Open a Node.js command prompt
  2. Navigate to the folder containing hash256.js
  3. Execute the script

Example output:

  • main.js: sha256-6134FFLCQYpH7x8gx29H1xJyRbitpf/guj5UGKhJ25Q=
  • sankeyChartStyling.js:  sha256-AR0uDO+9h8nu9EyJotSinZ2APDWD5Ja2JmdFcZCH1Xo=

Note: If additional JavaScript resource files are included, their corresponding sha256- integrity keys must also be added to the index.json file under the resources section.

Similarly, the file names must be updated in hash256.js before generating integrity keys for those files.

Core Enhancement: Top-N Parent and Top-M Child Logic

The following snippets are representative excerpts from the working implementation.
Full scripts are intentionally not published, as this widget was delivered as part of an enterprise engagement.

In the widget, the SAC data binding is first normalized into an array (data) containing parent node, child node, and measure value fields.

Step 1: Aggregate Measure by Parent

const parentTotals = {};
data.forEach(row => {
  parentTotals[row.parentNode] =
    (parentTotals[row.parentNode] || 0) + Number(row.measureValue);
});

Step 2: Rank and Retain Top-N Parents

const topParents = Object.entries(parentTotals)
  .sort((a, b) => b[1] - a[1])
  .slice(0, TOP_N_PARENT_NODES)
  .map(entry => entry[0]);

Step 3: Rank and Retain Top-M Children per Parent

const filteredLinks = [];
topParents.forEach(parent => {
  const children = data
    .filter(row => row.parentNode === parent)
    .sort((a, b) => b.measureValue - a.measureValue)
    .slice(0, TOP_N_CHILD_NODES);

  children.forEach(child => {
    filteredLinks.push({
      source: parent,
      target: child.childNode,
      value:  child.measureValue
    });
  });
});

Step 4: Rebuild Nodes

const nodes = [...new Set(
  filteredLinks.flatMap(l => [l.source, l.target])
)].map(name => ({ name }));

Step 5: Render Sankey

sankey.nodes(nodes).links(filteredLinks).layout(32);

The rendering follows the SAP sample approach; the innovation lies in the data-transformation logic.

Once all required files and script updates are ready, let’s deploy the custom widget into SAP Analytics Cloud.

Deploy the Custom Widget

  1. Create a ZIP File:
    • Include main.js, index.json, and optional styling files in a .zip file.
  2. Upload to SAP Analytics Cloud:
    • Navigate to the Custom Widgets section in SAC.
    • Upload the .json and .zip files.
  3. Test the Widget:
    • Add the custom widget to a story and configure data sources.

Select the JSON metadata file from your local system.

Next, select the resource file that is .zip file of main.js, index.json and styling.js or any other file related to this chart.

Now you can the widget in "Custom Widgets" section.

Observe the warning messages below with and/without integrity checks in the list of custom widgets

We have done custom widget deployment and will use the same in stories. Let's see how to access this in story 2.0.

 

From the builder panel, select your data model, set measure, set a hierarchical dimension and edit the default colors of the different depths from the Styling panel.

Below screenshot show the usage of the Styling.JS file.

In case the java script files get modified / tampered you get the below error while creating chart using custom widget in SAC story.

Validated Sankey Variants  - Let's validate 3 different scenarios

  • SAP sample Sankey (baseline):

entry.title: Re: How to Add Dynamic Text to Chart Based on Input Contr...
entry.content:
@Fiona_ 

Create a script variable which can later be bind to Dynamic Text. Now Read the Input control selection using the API and then assign "k" or "m" to script variable based on the value selected.

selectionCode = "";  // Create the Script Variable before assigning

var selection = InputControl_1.getInputControlDataSource().getActiveSelectedMembers(); // Read MTD or QTD

for (var i = 0; i < selections.length; i++) {
    var selectedId = selections[i].id;
    
    if (selectedId === "MTD") {
        selectionCode = "k";
        break; 
    } else if (selectedId === "QTD") {
        selectionCode = "m";
        break;
    }
}

 

You can assign the script variable selectioncode to dynamic text.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: TM - Output request - Sender Country Can't be Initial
entry.content:
Hi together!

summarizing the origin of the "sender country" in TM output:

In the freight order the business partner "Shipper" must be set.

You can either set it manually or automatically by shipper and consignee determination.

 

Automatic Shipper and Consignee Determination:

For this to work, you have to go into "Assign Business Partners to Company Codes" app F8408

After assigning a BP to your company code, the automatic shipper determination will work for all new freight order.

 

Workaround for existing freight orders: set the determination to "Manual Entry" and then back to "Automatic Shipper and Consignee Determination". This way the correct BP is found.

If you know a better way to fix existing FOs, let me know in the comment section!

 

BR Marcel

entry.title: Calculation View Features of 2025 QRC4
entry.content:
Within the time frame of 2025 Q4, several new calculation view features have been released in SAP Business Application Studio when connected to SAP HANA Cloud database QRC4. Some of these features are highlighted below. You can find examples that illustrate the individual features here. An overview of features of other releases can be found here.

Key Indicators

To support the decision on which columns a join should be defined or which cardinality should be set the key column indicator highlights columns that belong to the key of a data source:

Information about key columns is shown in join nodes and derived from underlying data sources. For table data sources the information is taken from the primary key information of the table. For calculation view data sources the key information is taken from the Semantics node. 

The key information is propagated within a model but not to the Semantics node, so that the decision about the Semantics node key can be done explicitly.
 
Use the key information to decide about join columns and join cardinality
 

Option to Control Column Pruning Behavior

The instantiation logic of calculation views reduces the number of processed columns and data sources based on the query. If instead a relational behavior similar to SQL views is intended all columns can be tagged with the property "Keep Flag". To simplify this, the option "Column Pruning Behavior" can be set to "OFF" which automatically sets the Keep Flag property for all columns:
 
Forcing additional columns into the aggregations can change the results, lead to higher resource consumption, and a decrease in performance. Therefore, Column Pruning Behavior should only be set to "OFF" if SQL view behavior is required.

Use this option to quickly compare the results with and without instantiation logic or if you want to mimic SQL behavior.
 

Open objects in Data Lineage and Impact Analysis Display

When analyzing the consumed objects of a calculation view (data lineage) or the consumers of a calculation view (impact analysis) the displayed objects of the same HDI container can now be opened in their associated editors:
 
Data Lineage
Impact Analysis
Data Lineage and Impact Analysis are available via the context menu of calculation view files:
 
Use this option to better understand the objects that are involved in lineage and impact analysis
 

Column Lineage SQL Function

Function SYS.GET_CALC_VIEW_COLUMN_DEPENDENCIES returns the base columns of individual calculation view columns. With this it becomes easy to track, for example, from which table a certain measure is coming.
 
IN Parameters
The parameters of the SQL function are:
- schema name of the calculation view to analyze
- the calculation view name
- the column to track or an empty string
- the option 'BASE' that defines the output details of the function
 
If the column name is left empty (''), all columns are treated as target columns.
Currently only the option BASE is available which omits intermediate objects and reports the underlying tables only.
 
System privilege CATALOG READ is required to execute the function.
 
Use this function to increase the insights into the behavior of the calculation view and to answer data auditing questions

MDS Cubes

Input parameters can now be used as client values during currency or unit conversion:

The input parameters do not have to be materialized when the mode Query Execution is selected.

The star joins can now include left outer joins:

and also restricted columns can be added to the MDS Cube:

Option Keep MDS Cube During Deployment

Per default MDS Cubes are newly created during deployment. This means that data that have been loaded into MDS Cubes will be deleted.
 
Set the Keep MDS Cube During Deployment flag if you want to keep the MDS Cube and thus the data also during redeployment:

 


This ensures that reporting on and loading of the MDS Cube can continue as before the redeployment.
 
Deployment of the calculation view is still possible as long as the calculation view changes would not lead to a situation in which the MDS Cube could not be loaded anymore. A redeployment will fail if it would lead to a MDS Cube that is not loadable anymore,  e.g., a column used in the MDS Cube is removed from the calculation view.

While the MDS Cube itself will not be modified by a successful redeployment of the calculation view when the flag is set, changed meta data such as changed hierarchies will be reflected when using the MDS Cube in SAP Analytics Cloud.
 
If the Keep MDS Cube During Deployment flag is set no changes to the MDS Cube are allowed and editing of the MDS Cube is blocked. If you want to edit the MDS Cube, unset the flag. Future redeployments will delete the data.
 
Use flag to ensure continuous reporting on MDS Cubes across deployments

entry.title: Re: For SAP CRM integration with external marketing syste...
entry.content:
Hey @Suheb, seems like I’m a bit late to the party, but this is a very common question.

From what I’ve seen in practice, OData itself isn’t the problem. Issues usually start when large amounts of data are pushed through it in one go. Most SAP OData services simply aren’t designed for huge bulk transfers without some form of control in between.

What typically works well is:

  • Pagination and filtering
  • Delta-based syncs (only changed records)
  • Asynchronous processing and queues in the middleware to decouple systems
  • Rate limiting and retry logic to avoid overload and handle temporary failures

In projects we run at MARINI, the key is that the middleware takes care of this orchestration. OData is just the connection layer and the stability comes from managing volume, timing, and retries in a controlled way.

We use this approach quite often when connecting SAP CRM or SAP C4C with marketing tools like HubSpot or Marketo especially when data volumes grow over time.

Happy to exchange experiences if you’re currently planning or scaling an integration like this.

Hi Chandra,

As I understood from your question, the base idea of what you want to achieve is to add your workflow a custom column which represents the status of MSTAE, MMSTA changes (whether the fields are changed or NOT).

If it is the case, you must read both inactive and snapshot (the active data before CR is created for the change scenario) and compare them.

Of course, there are several ways to do that but as you mentioned, you need to read the data from both data source points using these read modes;

  • if_usmd_model_ext=>gc_readmode_default [for staging]
  • if_usmd_db_adapter=>gc_readmode_no_inact [for snapshot]

Best Regards,

Beykan

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content:
I’ll restate my entire problem in case there’s a simpler solution that doesn’t require the trigger approach I initially considered.

I want to move some tables to a remote server to save space on my main database. However, the SQL statements that access these tables come from many different sources (EXEs, stored procedures, triggers, etc.), which makes it impractical to modify all of them.

To avoid changing those existing sources, I was considering creating a proxy table for each moved table and adding an INSTEAD OF trigger to handle insert, update, and delete operations. The trigger would redirect these operations to the remote table, allowing all existing SQL statements to continue working without modification.

Of course I dont have problem with insert statements, and my procedure for creating the relevant triggers looks like this:

create or replace procedure dba.MoveTableToLogDB(@TableName varchar(100), Async bit default 1)
begin
	execute immediate ('drop table  if exists dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB');
	execute immediate ('create existing table dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB at ''LogDB.LogDB.LogDB.' || @TableName || '''');
	------------------------Insert	
	if  Async = 1 then
		execute immediate ('' || 
		(select 'create or replace trigger "' || @TableName || '_01_Before_Insert" before insert order 1 on "dba"."' || @TableName  
		|| '" 
		referencing new as "new_rec" for each row begin ' || 
		'trigger event ExecuteImmediate(ExecuteStatement=''insert into dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB values(''''''||' ||
		(select list('"new_rec"."' || cname || '"', '||'''''',''''''||' order by colno) from sys.syscolumns where tname = @TableName)
		|| '||'''''')''); rollback trigger; end;'
		from dummy)
		);
	else
		execute immediate ('' || 
		(select 'create or replace trigger "' || @TableName || '_01_Before_Insert" before insert order 1 on "dba"."' || @TableName  
		|| '" 
		referencing new as "new_rec" for each row begin insert into dba.' || @TableName || '_LogDB values(' ||
		(select list('"new_rec"."' || cname || '"', ',' order by colno) from sys.syscolumns where tname = @TableName)
		|| '); rollback trigger; end;'
		from dummy)
		);
	end if;
end;



create or replace event ExecuteImmediate handler
begin
	declare @ExecuteStatement long varchar;
	set @ExecuteStatement       = event_parameter('ExecuteStatement');
	execute immediate with result set on (@ExecuteStatement);
end;

entry.title: Re: SAP S4Hana Public Cloud - Custom CDS View - How do I create a view that extends Condition Record
entry.content:
Hello @JJackson

Thank you for your question

Based on what you described, it seems you might be running into potential modelling limitations. Generally sales pricing condition records can be deemed generic, basically saying  that the keys depend on the condition table. Which means a single CDS like SlsPrcgConditionRecord will not always expose Customer Group ½ or Condition Table as clean joinable fields and it will not necessarily ship with an association to your product text or your sales order cubes.

I would like to better understand what you need and therefore I have some questions:

  1. Are you trying to find/define condition amount during a specific timeframe?
  2. Do you need Condition Table plus Customer Group ½ keys?
  3. Is the effective price and not the master record your goal? In other words, do you really need “which price applies” or to “show you the condition record master data”?

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Common Challenges in Approving SAP Access Requests – Practical Lessons
entry.content:
Approving SAP access requests is a daily activity in many organisations, but it is often underestimated. In several SAP security and access governance projects, access approvals have later turned out to be the root cause of audit findings and access risks.

This post shares common challenges seen during SAP access request approvals and practical lessons that can help organisations improve their approval process.

1. Unclear Role Design and Job Definitions

Access approvals depend heavily on how clearly business roles and system roles are defined. When job roles are vague or system roles are poorly named, approvers struggle to understand what access is being granted.

For example, if a user works as an accountant, the approver should easily know whether the request is for a local, regional, or global accounting role. When role names do not reflect their actual purpose, approvals become guesswork rather than informed decisions.

Lesson learned:
Clear role naming and well-defined job roles make approvals faster and safer.

2. Too Many Approval Steps

In some SAP environments, access requests go through multiple approval layers. While this may look secure on paper, it often slows down the process without improving control.

If approvers do not understand the user’s job or the role’s content, their approval adds little value. Meaningful approvals come from people who understand both the business requirement and the system access.

Lesson learned:
Fewer, well-informed approvers are more effective than many uninformed ones.

3. Accumulation of Roles Over Time

Users often change roles, projects, or departments. However, their SAP access is not always cleaned up accordingly. Over time, users collect multiple roles, which can result in excessive or conflicting access.

This “access build-up” increases compliance risk and makes it difficult to understand what access a user truly needs.

Lesson learned:
Removing unnecessary access is just as important as granting new access.

4. Lack of Clear Role Ownership

A common challenge is unclear ownership of system roles. When no one is responsible for a role’s content, approvers cannot be confident that the role provides only the required access.

Role owners play a critical role in maintaining trust in the access approval process. They ensure that roles remain aligned with business needs and compliance requirements.

Lesson learned:
Every role should have a clearly defined owner who is accountable for its content.

5. Limited Visibility into Access Risks

Overlapping roles can unintentionally grant users access beyond their job needs. Without proper visibility, this “access leakage” often goes unnoticed until an audit or security review.

Regular monitoring helps organisations identify risky access combinations early and take corrective action.

Lesson learned:
Access risks should be reviewed continuously, not only during audits.

Practical Recommendations

Based on experience from multiple SAP access governance initiatives, the following practices help improve access approvals:

Design system roles with clear naming and scope

Allow business approvers to reject unjustified requests

Avoid unnecessary approval layers

Review and clean up unused roles regularly

Start with minimal access and expand only when needed

Monitor access risks on a regular basis

Closing Thoughts

Access request approval is not just a technical step it is a governance decision. When roles are clear, ownership is defined, and approvals are meaningful, organisations reduce access risks and improve audit readiness.

Structured access governance and continuous reviews make SAP access management both secure and practical in daily operations.

For a more detailed discussion on SAP access approval challenges, you can read the extended version here: https://s4access.com/blogs/Typical-Challenges-in-Approving-SAP-Access-Requests

entry.title: Re: Assessing the number of messages in SAP integration S...
entry.content:
SAP doesn’t publish a simple “per message” USD price for Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) / Integration Suite because it’s sold as subscription packages. The cost depends on the plan you choose and the number of messages included. Here’s the latest publicly available pricing guidance in USD from SAP’s Discovery Center:

💵 SAP Integration Suite (CPI) Pricing in USD

Plan Type Monthly Subscription (USD) Messages Included per Month Notes

Starter~$1,000 / month50,0001 tenant, up to 10 custom iFlows
Standard~$3,000 / month10,0001 tenant, broader integration scenarios
Premium~$9,000 / month10,000,0004 tenants, advanced B2B/B2G features

Sources: SAP Discovery Center pricing calculator and SAP Integration Suite documentation.

⚠️ Important Notes

  • Overage Charges: If you exceed the included message quota, SAP bills extra per block of messages (pricing varies by contract).
  • SAP-to-SAP Integrations: Unlimited and free if you use SAP’s prebuilt content.
  • Currency: Prices are quoted in USD but may vary by region and contract terms.
  • Pay-As-You-Go (CPEA): SAP also offers consumption-based pricing where you pay per message traffic unit, typically starting around $0.007–$0.01 per message depending on volume.

entry.title: Re: Settlement rule from AUC to Final asset works only fo...
entry.content:
Hello @GabrielaTrasakova 

Thank you for your question

What you described typically happens when the AuC settlement is executed ledger by ledger. If you settle first in OL or 2L and the systems considers the run as complete, the next run can show you that there is nothing to settle although you still see values in the other ledger. In public cloud, when you use Execute Settlement for AuC, you should normally leave the Ledger field empty to post in all ledgers in one run. See  Assets Under Construction: Management and Settlement for more details.

This Blog provides some good insights: Asset Postings with Universal Parallel Accounting

Based on the fact that it does not work on one project and the others work well, this might be a configuration issue.

I suggest you:

  • Check the settlement rule, which might have been changed in the last month. Check whether the rule line is maintained only for ledger OL or only for ledger 2L. If necessary, adjust it so it applies to all relevant ledger or you may maintain rules per ledger if your process requires that. See: Ledger-Specific Settlement Rules and Parallel Accounting for more details.
  • Ensure you run the settlement correctly by leaving the ledger blank. This will ensure the posting is created for all ledgers. Then execute it.
  • If you already posted only in one ledger reverse the incorrect settlement posting and then rerun AIBU with the ledger empty.
  • You can use Display Line Items in General Ledger app to filter by Ledger =0L & 2L to confirm both of your postings exist.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Unit of measure
entry.content:
HI,

Anyone able to help in following query.

How to set up unit of measure for materials in such manner that number of decimals remains  zero.

The units of measure in question is pieces (PC).

 

Background:

There are materials for which the requirement is to handle materials as PC (pieces) with base unit of measure and CAS (case) as alternative unit of measure.  The requirement is to see the stock both in pieces (PC) and full packages (CAS).

 

We know that :

The pieces ‘PC’ unit of measure is maintained via configuration via tr CUNI, via Internal unit ‘ST’ (MSEH1), for which External unit PC (MSEH3 - is assigned). In t Tr SPRO>SAP NetWeaver>General settings> Check units of measurement.

(In Finnish SAP GUI, the unit (MSEH1) equals as follows:

PC ‘piece ‘ = KPL ‘kappale’

CAS ‘case’ = PAK ‘paketti’. Finnish client).

 

SAP recommends to maintain the smallest possible unit of measure (PC) as base unit of measure, and the bigger unti of measure (CAS) as alternative unit of measure.

This is maintained in Material Master tr MM02, in Additional data, in ‘Unit of Measure’-sheet.

98 pieces (PC) in one case (CAS)

This set up brings value 0,010 to field AZSUB ‘Number of Lower- Level Units’, in tr MM02 Material data>Additional data>sheet Unit of Measure. Meaning, SAP uses  three decimals in this field  Number of Lower- Level Units’, (AZSUB), instead of full decimals. In reality 98 pieces /  1 case = 0,0102040816326531. 

Now, in a withdraval of 7 pieces from the stock, via physical inventory counting , the stock quantity is being calculated as follows:

Set up details in tr MM02: 98 pcs in one (1) case

Current stock in system in tr MMBE : 980 pcs

Number of Lower- Level Units in tr MM02:  0,0102040816326531 (1 case divided by 98 pcs =  0,0102040816326531)

 

Business transation happens: Inventory counting result: 973 pcs

Outcome: SAP calculates resulting stock in PC (piece) as 973,042 (0,929 x 98 = 973,042), instead of 973, 000 pcs. Meaning, SAP uses rounded three decimal case value in the formula.

Alternative unit if measure, CAS, is  counted as 9,929  cases as follows:

0,0102040816326531  x 973 pcs = 9,928571428571466 cases. This is rounded into 9,929  cases with  3 decimals

                                          

 

What settings should be maintained in tr CUNI (Tr SPRO>SAP NetWeaver>General settings> Check units of measurement) for External unit 'PC' ? In order to fix this.

  • Choose Units of measurement>Choose Unit ST>Choose Details> Field: Decimal places (T006-DECAN)
    • SAP says ‘This parameter determines the number of decimal places with which this measurement unit is displayed’
  • Choose Units of measurement>Choose Unit ST>Choose Details> Field: Decimal pl. rounding (T006-ANDEC).
    • SAP says ‘The number of decimal places to which this measurement unit should be rounded.’

 

So far have used value zero in both fields, but it is not changing the functionality.

 

If there is documentation giving details for the area, would appreciate to get the links.

 

Best regards, 

Asta Usvakari

entry.title: SCC - Mudança na Gestão contributiva da Segurança Social Portugal
entry.content:
English Version below

Sumário executivo

A Simplificação do Ciclo Contributivo (SCC) introduz um novo modelo de comunicação de remunerações e apuramento de contribuições que elimina a tradicional Declaração de Remunerações (DR). A Segurança Social passa a calcular automaticamente as obrigações contributivas de cada trabalhador, cabendo à entidade empregadora apenas confirmar, alterar ou complementar os valores antes de proceder ao pagamento.

O resultado é uma redução significativa de burocracia, maior previsibilidade de encargos e transparência para empresas e trabalhadores.

Publicação: Anuncio da Simplificação do ciclo contributivo pela Segurança Social(20 de Novembro de 2025).

 

Objetivos das mudanças legais e da adoção da Plataforma de Interoperabilidade

  • Automatizar o apuramento mensal de contribuições, libertando as empresas de tarefas repetitivas.
  • Garantir coerência dos dados através da recolha direta de vínculos, taxas, absentismo das baixas e remunerações existentes na Segurança Social.
  • Fomentar a utilização da Plataforma de Serviços de Interoperabilidade (PSi) para uma integração segura entre os sistemas de Recursos Humanos e a Segurança Social, sobretudo para entidades com 10 ou mais trabalhadores.
  • Padronizar prazos:
    • Confirmação/alteração de valores até dia 20 do mês seguinte.
    • Pagamento das contribuições entre dia 1 e 25.
  • Reforçar a transparência e fiabilidade do registo contributivo dos trabalhadores, com consulta em tempo real no Portal da Segurança Social.

Ver vídeo de apresentação

 

Principais alterações legais (Decreto-Lei 127/2025 & Decreto Regulamentar 7/2025) – síntese

Apresentamos a síntese dos diplomas legais, sendo que o ponto 2 é o que impacta na localização da SAP, derivado de referir-se á Declaração de remunerações (art. 40.º CC):

  1. Comunicação de admissão de trabalhadores (art. 29.º CC & art. 5.º DR):
    • Passa a ser realizada exclusivamente via Segurança Social Direta/PSi.
    • Prazo reduzido: até ao início da execução do contrato (antes: 15 dias antes).
    • Presunção de vínculo em falta cai de 12 meses para 3 meses.
  2. Declaração de remunerações (art. 40.º CC, 20.º, 13.º-A, DR):
    • Substituição da entrega da DR por aceitação/confirmação de valores apurados pelo sistema.
    • Confirmação obrigatória até dia 20; omissão equivale a aceitação automática.
    • Novas contraordenações para falta de confirmação/correção (limite de 60 dias).
    • Deixa de se poder utilizar o código “6” da declaração de remunerações, havendo obrigação de entrega de declaração de substituição
    • As entidades empregadoras com menos de 10 trabalhadores podem efetuar as comunicações e declarações no serviço da Segurança Social Direta.
  3. Pagamento (art. 43.º CC)
    • Novo intervalo: dia 1-25 do mês seguinte (antes 10-20).
  4. Suprimento oficioso (art. 40.º-A CC; arts. 27.º-30.º DR)
    • Segurança Social pode lançar remunerações em falta com base nos seus dados, notificando a entidade empregadora.
  5. Regras de tempos de trabalho (art. 16.º DR; art. 70.º CC)
    • Equivalência de 1 dia por cada 5 h em regimes à hora/parciais; máx. 30 dias/mês.
  6. Calendário de adoção
    • Adesão voluntária: 1 jan 2026 → 31 dez 2026 (irreversível).
    • Obrigatório para todas as empresas a partir de 1 jan 2027.

 

Impacto em SAP

A mudança referida no ponto 2 das alterações legais impacta diretamente o processo de envio das remunerações hoje coberto pelo report standard RPC_PAYPT_DRI.

A segurança Social estabelece que a comunicação deve ser feita via Web Service através da Plataforma de Serviços de Interoperabilidade. Caso a entidade tenha menos de 10 trabalhadores, pode também fazê-lo através do portal da Segurança Social.

No mundo SAP, a grande maioria das empresas utilizadoras, terá sempre que gerar as declarações totais porque o mais habitual é a grande maioria dos empregados ter pagamentos varáveis e absentismos desconhecidos pela segurança social.

Assim a SAP está em contacto permanente com a Segurança Social para avaliar todos os serviços SCC que exigem integração, tal como para esclarecer as dúvidas que surgem nestes serviços.

Estamos neste momento a analisar, quais os serviços que iremos disponibilizar (os mais relevantes), e o esforço para que em breve seja anunciada a data de entrega destes serviços relevantes para as empresas nossas clientes, tendo como objetivo melhoria do processo.

Nós iremos manter este documento atualizado

EN Version

 

Executive Summary

Executive Summary

The Simplification of the Contributive Cycle (SCC) introduces a new model of reporting of remuneration and clearance of contributions that eliminates the traditional Remuneration Declaration (DR). Social Security automatically calculates the contributory obligations of each employee, and it is up to the employer only to confirm, change or supplement the values before proceeding with the payment.

The result is a significant reduction in red tape, greater predictability of burdens and transparency for businesses and workers.

Publication: Social Security announcement of Contributive Cycle simplification (November 20th, 2025)

 

Objectives of legal changes and adoption of the Interoperability Platform

  • Automate monthly contributions clearance, freeing companies from repetitive tasks.
  • Ensure consistency of data through direct collection of employment relationships, contribution rates, sick leave absenteeism and remunerations, available in Social Security.
  • Foster the use of the Interoperability Services Platform (PSi) for a secure integration between Human Resources systems and Social Security, especially for entities with 10 or more workers.
  • Standardize deadlines:
    • Confirmation/change of values until the 20th of the following month.
    • Payment of contributions between the 1st and 25th.
  • Strengthen the transparency and reliability of the contributory register of workers, with real-time consultation on the Social Security Portal.

See the presentation Video

 

Main legal changes (Decree-Law 127/2025 & Regulatory Decree 7/2025) – summary

In the following, a summary of the legal acts is presented; the 2nd point is the one that impacts the localization of SAP, as it refers to the Remuneration Statement (art. 40 CC):

  1. Communication on the admission of workers (Article 29 CC & Article 5 DR):
    • To be carried out exclusively via Direct Social Security/PSi.
    • In case of reduced term: until start of contract execution (before: 15 days before).
    • Presumption of missing employment relationship drops from 12 months to 3 months.
  2. Remuneration statement (Article 40 CC , article 20.º& article 13.º-A, DR):
    • Replacement of Remuneration Statement delivery by acceptance/confirmation of the values determined by the system.
    • Confirmation required by day 20; omission is equivalent to automatic acceptance.
    • New regulatory offences for missing confirmation/correction (60 days limit).
    • It is no longer possible to use code “6” in the remuneration declaration, and there is an obligation to submit a replacement declaration.
    • Employers with fewer than 10 employees may submit communications and declarations through the Social Security Direct service.
  3. Payment (Art. 43 CC)
    • New interval: day 1-25 of the following month (before 10-20).
  4. Own supply (Art. 40a CC; Rules 27-30 DR)
    • Social Security can post missing remunerations based on their data and notify the employer entity.
  5. Working time rules (Art. 16 DR; Art. 70 CC)
    • Equivalence of 1 day for every 5 hours in hourly/partial regimens; max. 30 days/month.
  6. Timetable for adoption
    • Voluntary adoption: 1 Jan 2026 → 31 Dec 2026 (irreversible).
    • Mandatory for all companies as of Jan 1, 2027.

 

Impact on SAP

The change referred to in point 2 of the legal changes directly impacts the process of sending the remuneration today covered by the standard report RPC_PAYPT_DRI.

Social Security states that communication must be done via the Interoperability Services Platform via Web Service. If the entity has fewer than 10 employees, it can also do so through the Social Security portal.

In the SAP world, most user companies will have to generate the all statements because usually most employees have variable payments and other absence events unknown to Social Security.

SAP is therefore in permanent contact with Social Security to evaluate all SCC services that require integration, as well as to clarify any questions that arise in these services.

SAP is currently assessing which of the services to provide (the most relevant) and the effort involved, so as to soon announce the respective delivery date of these relevant services, with the aim of improving the processes for SAP customers.

We will keep this document update!!

entry.title: What’s New in SAP HANA Cloud – December 2025
entry.content:
As the year draws to a close and the holiday season is approaching, we’re excited to share one more set of updates before 2025 wraps up. The Q4 release of SAP HANA Cloud delivers a focused set of innovations designed to further improve operational efficiency, resilience, developer productivity, and more.

Let’s deep dive into key innovations included in the December 2025 release:

 

SQL Tools for Administration in SAP HANA Cloud Central

Property Graph Viewer in Database Administration Tooling

With the Q4 release, SAP HANA Cloud Central introduces a property graph viewer directly within the database administration tooling. This viewer allows you to visually explore property graphs, where entities are represented as vertices and relationships as edges. A common example is modeling airports as vertices and flight routes as directed edges, including properties such as distance. You can apply filters to vertices and edges and enhance their analysis by applying built-in graph algorithms like neighborhood exploration, shortest path, or Cypher-based filtering.

The main value of the property graph viewer is faster understanding of complex relationships stored in graph structures. Instead of relying on raw query results, you can visually explore how entities are connected and quickly identify patterns, dependencies, or anomalies. This makes graph data more accessible not only to technical experts but also to solution architects and analysts who benefit from an intuitive, visual representation of relationships.

SQL Console Background Activities

SQL console background activities enable long-running SQL statements to continue executing independently of the browser session. You can now start a statement, close the browser, and return later to review the results without interrupting execution. This capability is fully integrated into the database administration tooling in SAP HANA Cloud Central.

This feature removes a long-standing friction point when working with complex or time-consuming SQL workloads. Administrators and developers no longer need to keep browser sessions open or worry about accidental disconnects. As a result, productivity increases, and operational tasks such as data preparation, analysis, or maintenance queries become more reliable and less disruptive.

Automatic Saving and Loading of SQL Statements

The SQL console now automatically saves its contents and connection details and restores them when you return. This behavior can be configured in the settings, allowing you to decide how persistent their SQL console sessions should be.

This enhancement provides continuity when switching tasks or sessions. You can pick up exactly where you left off, without re-establishing connections or recovering lost SQL statements. It improves day-to-day efficiency and reduces context switching, especially for administrators and developers working across multiple systems.

Application for Schemas and Deployment Infrastructure Containers

A new application in the database administration tooling provides a consolidated view of schemas and SAP HANA deployment infrastructure (HDI) containers within a subaccount. These can optionally be grouped by their associated SAP HANA database instance. You can examine detailed metadata, including Cloud Foundry organization and space information, instance IDs, and links to the associated database. From there, you can directly navigate to the database instance or open a SQL Console or database explorer connection.

This application simplifies landscape transparency for administrators. Instead of piecing together information across tools, you can quickly identify where schemas and containers live, understand their context, and jump directly into analysis or troubleshooting. This is especially valuable in larger environments with many applications and database instances.

 

Multi-Model and Machine Learning Updates

With the Q4 2025 release of SAP HANA Cloud, we continue to strengthen embedded Machine Learning and AI capabilities across the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL), the Automated Predictive Library (APL), and the Natural Language Processing (NLP) Services. These enhancements focus on making advanced analytics easier to use, more consistent across scenarios, and better suited for real-world business data.

Key highlights of this release are:

  • A new unified time series procedure, serving developers to utilize the same interface across different times series algorithms
  • text embedding model enhancements, supporting output vector dimensionality reduction, while maintaining retrieval accuracy
  • a new cross encoder model with the NLP services, for accurately re-ranking search results
  • text column input, text embedding operators with AutoML classification and regression models
  • text tokenization enhancements supporting regular expression token filtering and a new text log parsing function for detecting and determining new log pattern
  • the HANA ML experiment monitor UI now supports visual model monitoring and drift analysis

To learn more about the new Multi-Model and Machine Learning updates, check out @ChristophMorgen‘s blogpost here.

Transforming Property Graphs into Knowledge Graphs

With the Q4 2025 release, SAP HANA Cloud introduces the ability to transform property graphs into knowledge graphs. This capability allows you to convert existing graph structures into a semantic, knowledge-graph representation without redesigning your data models from scratch. It enables you to work with different graph paradigms on top of the same underlying data.

This innovation helps you maximize data utility by seamlessly switching between property graph and knowledge graph models depending on your needs. You are no longer restricted to a single data representation and can choose the most appropriate graph model for analytics, reasoning, or integration scenarios. As a result, you gain greater operational efficiency, improved interoperability between graph models, and more flexibility in how you explore and reuse graph-based data.

Learn more about transforming property graphs into knowledge graphs on this blogpost by @shabana .

 

Calculation View Modeling Updates

Column Lineage Insights for Graphical Calculation Views

SAP HANA Cloud now allows you to gain column lineage insights for graphically modeled calculation views by calling an SQL table function. This capability provides transparency into how output columns are derived from underlying sources, with lineage tracked across graphical modeling steps and stopping at functions or procedures.

By making lineage information easily accessible, this feature improves model quality and trust. Developers can better understand complex models, speed up enhancements, and reduce errors during refactoring. For architects and analysts, clearer lineage increases confidence in the data and supports governance and audit requirements.

Input Parameters for Currency and Unit Conversion in MDS Cubes

Input parameters can now be used to specify client values for currency and unit conversion when working with multidimensional services (MDS) cubes. These values no longer need to be materialized, and conversions can be defined dynamically at query runtime.

This enhancement increases flexibility in analytical scenarios. You can adapt conversions based on runtime context without redesigning models or creating additional persisted data. It enables more dynamic reporting and simplifies scenarios where conversion logic depends on user input or business context.

Restricted Columns in MDS Cubes

With Q4, restricted columns can be added to MDS cubes and evaluated at query execution time. If runtime evaluation is not possible, deployment fails with a clear notification. This approach avoids mandatory materialization of input parameters while still ensuring correctness.

The key value lies in greater runtime control and reduced data preparation overhead. You can now influence how restricted columns are processed without forcing early decisions during modeling, leading to more flexible cubes and more efficient execution.

Visibility of Key Columns When Modeling Joins

When defining joins in calculation views, key columns are now visually indicated. This makes it easier to understand join semantics and identify important relationships directly in the modeling UI.

By highlighting key columns, this feature helps you create star joins with greater confidence and accuracy. It reduces modeling errors, improves data consistency, and ultimately results in higher-quality analytical models.

Left Outer Joins in Star Joins of MDS Cubes

SAP HANA Cloud now supports left outer joins in star joins for MDS cubes. This expands the range of scenarios that can be modeled using multidimensional services.

The benefit is faster adoption of MDS cubes in additional analytical use cases. You gain more flexibility in how dimensions and facts are combined, without having to fall back to alternative modeling approaches.

If you are interested in discovering more about Calculation View modeling updates, check out this blogpost by @JanZwickel.

 

Cloud Reliability and Total Cost of Ownership

The Q4 release of SAP HANA Cloud is also introducing significant enhancements to strengthen the service's reliability while reduction the overal total cost of ownership at the same time.

Multi-Region Disaster Recovery

In early Q4 we extended disaster recovery capabilities beyond multiple availability zones within a single region to selected, distant regions. The initial scope focused on North America, using Amazon Web Services with a pairing between US East (VA) and US West (Oregon). Support includes SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake Files, while multi-tenancy is excluded in the initial phase.

This innovation significantly improves resilience against regional outages. By maintaining a secondary system in a distant region, customers can better protect critical workloads and ensure business continuity. The offering starts with a defined scope and will expand stepwise to additional regions, cloud providers, and features.

We're happy to share, that we will be extending our offering to Europe, early in January 2026. Customers will then be able to protect SAP HANA Cloud workloads across EU Central (Frankfurt) and EU South (Milan), improving resilience against regional outages with a secondary system in a predefined, geographically distant region. This expansion will help EU-based and global customers strengthen business continuity while meeting regional availability and data residency needs, with additional regions and enhancements planned based on demand.

Active/Active Read-Enabled High Availability

Synchronous replicas in a "high availability" configuration ensure increased reliability via autonomous failover capabilities to standby systems, in case of outages or other incidents.
But, such high availability setups require redundant resources, which traditionally remain idle during normal operations. With the new active/active read-enabled option, SAP HANA Cloud allows these secondary systems to actively handle read-intensive analytical workloads. In the initial scope, client-side statement routing enables applications to direct analytical queries to these replicas.

This approach improves cost efficiency and performance at the same time. You can offload analytical workloads from the primary system while still preserving full high-availability readiness. The same resources that ensure resilience now also deliver day-to-day business value.

Automatic Up-Scaling Storage

SAP HANA Cloud now supports automatic storage upscaling to prevent disk-full situations. When enabled by administrators, the system can double the initially provisioned storage size - up to a customer-defined maximum - once usage reaches 98%. Alerts notify administrators, and a minimum cycle time of six hours applies between scaling events.

This capability helps avoid critical outages caused by full disks while still keeping costs under control. Administrators gain more time to react to growing storage needs and can define clear boundaries for automatic scaling, balancing safety and predictability.

 

Seamless Integration with  SAP Business Data Cloud

As announced at SAP TechEd 2025, SAP HANA Cloud will integrate in a bi-directional manner with SAP Business Data Cloud, to consume and produce data products and thereby combine the best out of two solutions. While the production of data products will become available in early 2026, the consumption is now possible with our latest release.

Native Consumption of Data Products

SAP HANA Cloud can now directly consume data products from SAP Business Data Cloud. Virtual table connections are created automatically, enabling seamless access from SAP HANA Cloud to the data product source.

This integration allows customers to extend SAP line-of-business applications with custom logic while relying on governed, reusable data products. It reduces integration effort and accelerates innovation by making enterprise data easier to access and combine.

 

Enhancements to SQL on Files

Delta Table Replication

Direct read-only access to Delta tables in the object storage or through Delta Sharing, which has been introduced since QRC 04/2024, has offered real-time analytics on the vast volume of data in files, without moving them into SAP HANA Cloud. With QRC 04/2025, it evolves further by offering replication capability for critical datasets, enabling faster queries with greater flexibility and robust data management.

This new Delta table-to-HANA replication offers granular controls, such as chunk-based initial load, which allows splitting the data into multiple chunks and loading them separately to make the initial load more manageable. Furthermore, when it comes to Change Data Capture (CDC), it allows either user-driven, version-based CDC or system-driven, scheduled CDC for full automation. 

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud’s new Delta table-to-HANA replication, take a look at @SeungjoonLee's blog post here.

Smart Data Access: Support for two new remote sources through Data Access Agent

Additionally, based on the newly introduced Smart Data Access (SDA) Data Access Agent from the last QRC 03/2025, read-only access to two new remote sources, Google Sheets and Oracle Database in the cloud, will be available from QRC 04/2025. 

The way of configuring and using them remains the same as for other previously supported remote sources, and for newly provisioned Data Access Agents, all new adapters are activated by default. To activate new adapters for a Data Access Agent that has already been provisioned and is currently in use, please refer to SAP Note 2600176 - SAP HANA Smart Data Access Supported Remote Sources for further details on how to activate them, as well as additional information on support. 

 

Datacenter Updates

In Q4 2025, we are announcing the availability of SAP HANA Cloud in these new BTP regions:

  • Italy (Milan) on AWS 
  • Germany (St. Leon-Rot) on SCI 
  • United Arab Emirates (Dubai) on SCI 
  • US West (Colorado) on SCI* 
  • Australia (Sydney) on SCI* 

* General availability is expected by the end of Q4 2025, when the respective BTP regions are planned to go live. See SAP Roadmap Explorer for details.

We continue our journey to give customers the freedom to choose their preferred infrastructure cloud provider by investing in regions on both hyperscalers and SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI). 

  • On AWS, we are announcing the availability of SAP HANA Cloud in a second European region: Italy (Milan). This establishes the technical foundation for multi-region disaster recovery within European borders. 

The first SCI region — Germany (Frankfurt) — was announced in Q3 2025, see blog post. Now, we are making SAP HANA Cloud available globally on SCI, by offering a second SCI region in Germany (with EU Access), as well as SCI regions in the U.S., Australia, and the UAE.

 

Further Updates

Native Multi-Tenancy: Tenant Move with Reduced Downtime

The enhanced tenant move process for SAP HANA Cloud native multi-tenancy splits the operation into a preparation phase and a short cutover phase. During preparation, tenant data is copied while the source tenant remains fully operational. Only during the final cutover is brief downtime required to apply delta changes and switch over.

This significantly reduces business downtime and gives you control over scheduling the cutover in low-impact time windows. It improves operational flexibility and minimizes risk during tenant reorganization.

Selective, Incremental Migration to SAP HANA Cloud

Selective, incremental migration allows you to migrate chosen parts of an SAP HANA 2.0 database to SAP HANA Cloud instead of moving everything at once. Migrations can be performed in smaller, manageable steps based on schemas or deployment infrastructure containers.

This approach reduces downtime, avoids migrating unused components, and makes large migrations more predictable. It allows you to better plan the transition to the cloud, while minimizing disruption.

Rule-Based Index Advisor

The new rule-based Index Advisor analyzes query usage patterns to identify index optimization opportunities. It recommends creating or dropping indexes for single-table filter queries and provides ready-to-execute SQL statements.

By automating index analysis, this feature improves performance while helping control costs. Administrators gain actionable insights without deep manual analysis, making database tuning more accessible and efficient.

Thanks for taking the time to explore the What’s New in SAP HANA Cloud on Q4 2025 innovations!

If you’d like to go deeper into the technical details of the December 2025 release, we recommend visiting the What’s New Viewer in the technical documentation. It provides a comprehensive overview of the full release scope. To stay informed about upcoming innovations, announcements, and best practices, follow the SAP HANA Cloud tag.

You can also find our latest blog posts by searching for the #whatsnewinsaphanacloud hashtag.

If you missed earlier What’s New webinars, you’ll find recordings of past sessions and upcoming events in our YouTube playlist. Our What’s New webinar covering the Q4 2025 innovations will be posted on this playlist very soon.

Do you have questions about SAP HANA Cloud or want to share your thoughts on the new features?
Join the conversation in the SAP HANA Cloud Community Q&A or leave a comment below. We’d love to hear from you!

Enjoy the holidays and have a great start into 2026!

entry.title: Re: Can the result of CALL TRANSFORMATION be empty?
entry.content:
1. Lines 6 to 8: is it possible that without error the XML is empty?
    • The XML is always filled after a successful transformation.
    • So, testing if the generated XML is empty or not makes no sense.
  2. Lines 11 and 16: isn't the generated XML always empty if there's an error, why testing if it's empty?
    • The XML can be partially filled after an exception because the transformation transforms field by field directly in the result variable. See the demonstration program (ABAP Unit / Run via Ctrl + Shift + F10).
    • But testing if the XML is empty or not after an exception makes no sense 99% of the time.
  3. Line 12: why considering that the attribute S2 is filled in all cases when the exception CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is raised, and why not using LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) instead?
    • CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is a generic exception with many possible texts as can be seen in SE24 (tab "Texts"), and these texts use S2 or not:
      CX_ROOT An exception occurred
      CX_TRANSFORMATION_ERROR The command CALL TRANSFORMATION triggered an exception
      CX_XSLT_EXCEPTION XSLT Exception
      XSLT_NOT_SUPPORTED XSLT is not (yet) supported on this platform
      CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR XSLT runtime error
      OUTPUT_SETTING_CONFLICT Conflict in output definition '&S2&', attribute '&S1&'
      IMPOSSIBLE_SECONDARY_RESULT Secondary result &AS1&1 cannot be created
      CONVERSION_IMPOSSIBLE Value '&S1&' cannot be converted to type '&S2&'
      UNSUPPORTED_CALL Form of function call for '&S1&' not supported
      BAD_KEY Invalid key '&S1&'
      BAD_URI Invalid document URI '&S1&'
      INVALID_PREFIX No declaration in scope for namespace prefix in '&S1&'
      NO_NODESET Value '&S1&' is not a nodeset
      PARSE_ERROR XML parsing error (&I1&) in '&S1&', line &I2&, column &I3&: &S2&
      UNKNOWN_OBJECT Unbound external object '&S1&'
      OUT_OF_MEMORY Out of memory
      NO_TREEFRAGMENT Value '&S1&' is not a tree fragment
      NO_TRANS_VALUE Not bound to a transformation
      PROGRAM_LOST XSLT program lost
      VAL_STACK_OVERFLOW Value stack overflow
      TRANS_VALUE Bound to a transformation
      SRC_STACK_OVERFLOW Source-context stack overflow
      RES_STACK_OVERFLOW Result-context stack overflow
      BAD_RESULT_CONTEXT No valid result context supplied
      BAD_PROGRAM No valid XSLT program supplied
      BAD_INTERNAL_VALUE Illegal internal value for external call
      BAD_EXTERNAL_VALUE Illegal external value from external call
      ACT_STACK_OVERFLOW Activation stack overflow
      BAD_SOURCE_CONTEXT No valid source context supplied
      INTERNAL_ERROR Internal error
      UNKNOWN_FUNCTION Call of unknown function
      FORMAT_ERROR Invalid XML format
      PROPVALUE_ERROR Invalid property value
      NOT_SUPPORTED Serialization is not supported
      ABAP_CALL_NO_IXML_OBJECT
    • Hence, it's a bad idea to overwrite a standard message.
    • LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) should be used instead.

Demo program for case 2:

 

REPORT zdemo.
CLASS ltcl_ DEFINITION FINAL
  FOR TESTING RISK LEVEL HARMLESS DURATION SHORT.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS partially_transform_if_fails FOR TESTING RAISING cx_static_check.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS ltcl_ IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD partially_transform_if_fails.
    DATA message TYPE bapiret2.

    message = VALUE #( number = '001' ).
    TRY.
        CALL TRANSFORMATION id
             SOURCE XML `<asx:abap xmlns:asx="http://www.sap.com/abapxml" version="1.0"><asx:values><DATA><ID>AA</ID><NUMBER>AAA</NUMBER></DATA></asx:values></asx:abap>`
             RESULT data = message.
        cl_abap_unit_assert=>fail( 'The transformation was expected to fail'
           && ' because the message number cannot contain alpha AAA' ).
      CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(error).
        cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_equals( act = message
                                            exp = VALUE bapiret2( id     = 'AA'
                                                                  number = '001' ) ).
    ENDTRY.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Re: SERVICE FLOW
entry.content: You can’t rely on valuation class for services in Public Cloud. Instead, you need to configure account determination rules (SSCUI/BRF+) or use catalogs/templates so the G/L account is derived automatically and users don’t have to guess.
